STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 1, 2024
KELLIE OOM
DA BLODGETT FOR CHILDREN
2172 Dean Lake Ave NE,
Grand Rapids, MI, 49505-4444
RE: License#: CB410201088
Dear KELLIE OOM:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on May 1, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201088
Licensee Group Organization: DA Blodgett for Children
Licensee Designee: Mary Catherine Muliett
Chief Administrator: KELLIE RENAE OOM
Name of Agency: DA BLODGETT FOR CHILDREN
Agency Address: 2172 Dean Lake Ave NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49505-4444
Agency Telephone #: 6164512021
Original Issuance Date: 06/02/1991
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 4/8/2024.
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

since last inspection 1 1

Others (identify person interviewed by role)
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (b) Verification of education.
Two of eleven new employee files reviewed did not have documentation that
verification of education was obtained prior to hire. Copies of degrees were
obtained but did not show the specific program.
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
• (3) An agency shall provide the licensee an
application for renewal of the license and
document the action not less than 60 calendar
days before the expiration date of the license. A
renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending
recommendation for disciplinary action of the
license.

One of six foster home files reviewed did not contain verification the renewal
application was provided to the licensee at least 60 days prior to the expiration of
the license.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not contain documentation the agency
made a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 days before the
expiration of the foster home license.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child
as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (ii) A physical examination every
14 months.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have a physical examination
completed every 14 months as required.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as
applicable; the department; and the foster

child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (ii) The foster child is absent
without legal permission.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have an incident report completed
and provided to the department licensing authority notifying the foster child’s
absence without legal permission.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have Updated Services Plan
completed timely as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
5/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/3/2022
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the IL
agreement was reviewed with the youth at least once every 90 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned cahnge
of placement or no later than three busines days after
an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
5/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/3/2022
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.

Seven of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
5/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/3/2022
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed, and two of three independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
5/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/3/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:

• Participating legal parents if the child is
temporary court ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to
each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and
accepted for treatment or services prior to or at
the first schedule appointment while the foster
caer case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/11/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/15/2023
5/12/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/3/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:

• Annotate on PATP if they were mailed, emailed, refused, etc.
• Review incident report requirements with staff.
• Update HR checklist to ensure education requirements are met prior to hire.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2024C0001263SE was initiated on 1/12/2024 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent utilized improper behavioral management by
poking a foster youth. The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of
licensing rules. The evaluation was thorough and well written. A CAP is pending
approval.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency Interim inspection was completed on 5/11/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 6/15/2023. The agency was cited for 13 violations, 7 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 7, there was an improvement in missed medicals and
medical passports. There was a slight increase in the number of late USP's, PATP
signatures not obtained or not obtained timely, missed FTM's and DHS 1105
forms not uploaded or not uploaded timely. The number of incidents of non-
compliance regarding independent living contracts remained the same. In 2022,
15 violations were established, 6 of which were repeated this year. The agency
will need to establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to
ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency has experienced some difficulties throughout the year due to
staff turnover, replacements, and lack of resources for youth that are hard to
place. The agency has put significant efforts to utilize the previous year CAP as
well as data to improve and monitor compliance and performance. Utilizing the
HLO has had a positive impact on medicals and dentals. In addition, the agency
implemented a significant change in visitations that improved parent/child
contacts.

Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency as well as coworkers. Staff did not report any concerns
that are specific to the agency but some frustration with some of the systemic
requirements.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing, and adoption services. All files were stored
securely including CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
__5/1/2024____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
05/02/2024
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
